review.title: Investigating Mathematical Models of Immuno-Interactions with Early-Stage Cancer under an Agent-Based Modelling Perspective
review.abstract: Many advances in research regarding immuno-interactions with cancer were developed with the help of ordinary differential equation (ODE) models. These models, however, are not effectively capable of representing problems involving individual localisation, memory and emerging properties, which are common characteristics of cells and molecules of the immune system. Agent-based modelling and simulation is an alternative paradigm to ODE models that overcomes these limitations. In this paper we investigate the potential contribution of agent-based modelling and simulation when compared to ODE modelling and simulation. We seek answers to the following questions: Is it possible to obtain an equivalent agent-based model from the ODE formulation? Do the outcomes differ? Are there any benefits of using one method compared to the other? To answer these questions, we have considered three case studies using established mathematical models of immune interactions with early-stage cancer. These case studies were re-conceptualised under an agent-based perspective and the simulation results were then compared with those from the ODE models. Our results show that it is possible to obtain equivalent agent-based models (i.e. implementing the same mechanisms); the simulation output of both types of models however might differ depending on the attributes of the system to be modelled. In some cases, additional insight from using agent-based modelling was obtained. Overall, we can confirm that agent-based modelling is a useful addition to the tool set of immunologists, as it has extra features that allow for simulations with characteristics that are closer to the biological phenomena.

metadata.title: Investigating Mathematical Models of Immuno-Interactions with Early-Stage Cancer under an Agent-Based Modelling Perspective

sections.text: 1 Examination of Mathematical Models of Immune InteractionsMany advances in research relating to immunointeractions with cancer have been developed using traditional differential equation (ODE) models, but these models are not effectively able to present problems in terms of individual localization, memory and emerging characteristics that are common characteristics of cells and molecules of the immune system. Agent-based modeling and simulation is an alternative paradigm for ODE models that overcomes these limitations. In this paper, we examine the potential contribution of agent-based modeling and simulation as compared to ODE modeling and simulation. We seek answers to the following questions: Is it possible to obtain an equivalent agent-based model from the ODE formulation? Are there any advantages of applying one method compared to the other? To answer these questions, we have considered three case studies that compare established mathematical models of immunointeractions with cancer-based early-stage case studies with those that have been redesigned and were redesigned under the DE.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that the solution to these problems is not to solve problems, but to solve problems that have arisen in the past.

sections.heading: Case studies
sections.text: The selection of the case studies is made taking into account aspects such as population size, modelling effort, model complexity, observation of the results of the ODEs and the number of modelled populations. The mathematical models chosen vary greatly within these aspects and therefore we can carry out a more robust analysis of our experiments, as in Table 1. The first case study considered is based on an ODE model that includes interactions between tumour cells and generic effector cells. The second case study supplements the previous model with the influence of IL-2 cytokine molecules on the immune reactions of effector cells against tumour cells. The final case study includes an ODE model of the interactions between effector cells, tumour cells and IL-2 and TGF-3 molecules. In all case studies both the mathematical model and the ABMS model are presented, the results are compared and the benefit of each approach is evaluated. The models differ in terms of the complexity of the interactions we are involved in the study, the number of the interactions of the substances and the problems of the BMS.

sections.heading: Related Work
sections.text: This year it has come to the point that it will only be a matter of time before it will happen, until it does.

sections.heading: Methodology
sections.text: In this section, we will outline the activities and methods necessary to achieve our objectives. We will examine case studies of established mathematical models that describe some immune cells and molecules that interact with tumor cells. These case studies were selected taking into account aspects such as the behavior of the units of the model, the size (and number) of populations involved, and the modeling effort involved. The original mathematical models are based on an agent-based approach and results in comparison. ABMS is able to represent space; however, since we have selected mathematical models that do not take into account spatial interactions, our respective ABMS models do not take into account space (distance) and how it would affect simulation outcomes. The results obtained from ODEs and ABMS were statistically compared with the Wilcoxon Rank Sum Test to formally determine whether they differ statistically from each other. This test is applied because it is robust if the populations are not normally distributed, the samples are not identical to the OBMS, and if the samples are not statistically accurate to the OBMS.

sections.heading: The agent-based model
sections.text: Two classes of active substances are defined: the tumour cell and the effector cell. The parameters and behaviours of the active substances corresponding to each state are shown in Table 3. All behaviours are derived from the mathematical model. In the table, each active substance has two different types of behaviour: reactive and proactive behaviour. State tables are frequently used in ABMS to show the different states in which entities may be located and how they move from one state to another (transitions).In our models, we also use events that should occur in the course of the simulation.The state table for the tumour cells is shown in Figure 2 (a), in which an active substance dies with increasing age or is killed by effector cells.In addition, the tumour cells contribute to the damage to the effector cells at a certain rate. The rates defined in the transitions are the same as those from the mathematical model (Table 4), in which an active substance is killed by proliferation or effector cells.

sections.heading: Experimental design for the simulations
sections.text: Four scenarios were investigated: different death rates of tumour cells (defined by parameters b), different apoptosis rates of effector cells (defined by parameters d) and different treatments (parameters s). Values for these parameters were determined from [2] (see Table 5). In the first three scenarios cancer treatment was considered, while in the fourth case no treatment was considered.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this is a very complex matter.

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text: An ODE model of tumor cell growth and its interactions with general immune effector cells was considered for re-design using ABMS. Four scenarios were examined taking into account small population numbers, and for only one of them the ABMS results were similar to the mathematical model. Observed differences were explained by the way each simulation approach is implemented, including their representation and processing of data. ODE simulations treat continuous values for entities, while ABMS are discrete agents. Furthermore, the stochastic behavior of ABMS and how it affects small populations also appears in the ODEs that the individual interactions between populations in ABMS lead to more chaotic behavior that does not occur at a higher aggregated level. Results analysis also shows that the conceptualized proliferation of the ABMS model from the mathematical equations does not always produce the same results from the ABMS results, 2 an alternative to achieve better results for a drug-based cell development in DE.

In the transition rate calculations, the TotalTumour variable corresponds to the total number of tumour cell agents, the TotalEffector variable to the total number of effector cell agents and TotalIL 2 to the total number of IL-2 agents. In addition to the active agents, there are two events in the simulation model: 1. Treatment S1, which adds effector cell agents according to the parameter s12. Treatment S2, which adds IL-2 agents according to the parameter s2.

sections.text: The experiment was carried out assuming the same parameters as the mathematical model (Table 9).For the ABMS model, the simulation was performed fifty times and the average result value for these iterations.Each iteration simulated a period corresponding to six hundred days and followed the same period used for the numerical simulation of the mathematical model.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text: The obtained results are shown in Figures 8, 9 and 10 for effector cells, tumour cells and IL-2, respectively. ABMS was validated by comparing its results with those of ODEs. As the figures show, the results are very similar for all populations; the growth and decline of all populations occur at similar times in both approaches. Furthermore, due to the large population sizes (around 104), ABMS model curves exhibit slightly irregular behavior, confirming the similar patterns observed in the results.15dE = dtcT (p1EI) () p1 − _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ q1Sµ1E + (16) 1 + SThese similarities are also confirmed by the Wilcoxon test results presented in Table 10.

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text: A mathematical model for the interactions between tumor cells, effector cells and the cytokine IL-2 was considered to investigate the possible contribution of the model construction from an ABMS perspective. Experiments show that the results are very similar, which is explained by the large population sizes taken into account in the experiments. In further experiments, the same model was also performed under small population sizes, and the results for the simulations were significantly more time and memory intensive than the ODEs due to the stochasticity and peculiarities of the approach discussed in the previous case study. sections.text: The experiment was carried out using the same parameters defined for the mathematical model (Table 13).For the ABMS model, the simulation was performed fifty times and the average result value for these runs was calculated.Each run simulated a period corresponding to six hundred days after the time interval used for the numerical simulation of the mathematical model.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text: The results for case 3 ODEs and ABMS simulations are therefore similar in Figures 12, 13, 14 and 15. Results show that the behavior of the curves for effector cells, tumor cells and IL-2 is similar in both paradigms, although the start time for population growth for ABMS varies for each run. Therefore, the numbers corresponding to the ABMS results plotted ten different runs to illustrate the variations.The observed differences occur for two reasons: (1) the ABMS stochasticity and (2) the agents individual behavior and their interactions. While the ODEs always use the same values for the parameters of the entire population, ABMS combinations result.

sections.heading: Summary
sections.text: The third case study covered interactions between effector cells, tumor cells, and two types of cytokines, IL-2 and TGF-3. Two important aspects were observed in the ABMS results: The first observation is that the TGF-3 population was not present in the simulation when using the parameters of the mathematical model, because its numbers are real values smaller than one; this indicates that there is a need for further validation of the model with real data to verify which paradigm result is closer to reality; and the second observed aspect is that ABMS produces additional patterns of population behavior (extreme cases) that differ from those of the mathematical model, which in turn could lead to the discovery of other real-world patterns that would not otherwise be detected by deterministic models.

sections.heading: Authors Contributions
sections.text: Grazziela Figueredo developed the agent-based simulation models, conducted the experiments and designed the manuscript. Peer-Olaf Siebers assisted in the creation of the manuscript and critically reviewed it for important intellectual content. Uwe Aickelin reviewed the manuscript and gave the final approval to the version to be published.

[25] compare the dynamics of a stochastic ABMS with those of the analogous deterministic compartment differential equation model for contagious disease spread.

An interesting philosophical analysis is conducted by Schieritz [26] analyses two arguments given in literature to explain the superiority of ABMS compared with ODEs: (1) “the inability of ODE models to explain emergent phenomena” and (2) “their flaw of not considering individual diversity”.
Similarly, Lorenz [27] proposes that three aspects be compared and that this helps with the choice between ODE and ABMS: structure, behaviour and emergence.
In disagreement with [26] mentioned earlier, the author states that ABMS is capable of capturing emergence, while the one-level structure of ODE is insufficient in that respect.
The differences between ODEs and ABMS when applied to classes of problems belonging to different levels of abstraction are well established in the literature [23].

metadata.abstractText: Many advances in research regarding immuno-interactions with cancer were developed with the help of ordinary differential equation (ODE) models. These models, however, are not effectively capable of representing problems involving individual localisation, memory and emerging properties, which are common characteristics of cells and molecules of the immune system. Agent-based modelling and simulation is an alternative paradigm to ODE models that overcomes these limitations. In this paper we investigate the potential contribution of agentbased modelling and simulation when compared to ODE modelling and simulation. We seek answers to the following questions: Is it possible to obtain an equivalent agent-based model from the ODE formulation? Do the outcomes differ? Are there any benefits of using one method compared to the other? To answer these questions, we have considered three case studies using established mathematical models of immune interactions with earlystage cancer. These case studies were re-conceptualised under an agent-based perspective and the simulation results were then compared with those from the ODE models. Our results show that it is possible to obtain equivalent agent-based models (i.e. implementing the same mechanisms); the simulation output of both types of models however might differ depending on the attributes of the system to be modelled. In some cases, additional insight from using agent-based modelling was obtained. Overall, we can confirm that agent-based modelling is a useful addition to the tool set of immunologists, as it has extra features that allow for simulations with characteristics that are closer to the biological phenomena.
